item.description:
Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (Comedy-Drama Thailand 2010 Directed by Apichatpong Weerasethakul 113 min)

 Apichatpong Weerasethakul's first feature-length narrative after 2007's Syndrome and a Century, wins Cannes official Palme d'Or and the unofficial best film title and finally gets screened in Boston. Unfortunately, the MFA scheduling is pretty awful: April 7 at 5:00 and 7:30, April 8 at 4:30 and Saturday, April 9 at 10:30 am. 

  Here is a synopsis of this comedy-drama from UK Guardian : 

  He's affectionately introduced at film festivals as "Joe", but I'll call him AW. Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives tells a familiar story on universal themes. A middle-aged man confronting imminent death from kidney disease has a reunion with members of his family and communes with the ghostly spirit of his late wife.

 AW has turned this simple tale into a work of magical realism that, like his previous pictures, touches on Zen Buddhism, reincarnation and the meaning of life, while at the same time treating with a certain obliquity the violent recent history and modernisation of his country. "It's about going back to the roots of things, what we have in our bodies, the primitive energy" - quote from Joe

One of his visitors, his xenophobic, ageing sister-in-law, Jen, looks down on foreigners, the most astonishing visitors, however, are the ghost of Boonmee's late wife and his long-lost son. The wife comes for dinner and stays the night, answering his question about the future  and forgiving him for any murders he may have committed during the course of his participation in the country's brutal suppression of communist insurgents.  The son is now a strange simian creature with bright-red, glowing eyes, he appears to have a role both in the chain of being and in the country's brutal politics

A coda concerns his funeral in a rather garish temple and is otherwise realistic, except that two characters sitting in a hotel room casually get up and leave for dinner while simultaneously remaining to watch TV.

If anything, Joe's sense of dream logic is more naturalistic than Lynch's, more grounded in the knowable world - as much, that is, as we can know about nature - and the luminous Uncle Boonmee is no exception.  Movieline 

A work of unostentatious beauty and uncloying sweetness, at once sophisticated and artless, mysterious and matter-of-fact, cosmic and humble, it asks only a measure of Boonmeevian acceptance: The movie doesn't mean anything-it simply is. Village Voice 

What is clear is that this is a director with a great sense of the magical and the mystical residing in the everyday. LA Times

Its really a shame that Uncle Boonmee has such  awkward screening times here in Boston. Hope you can fit it into your schedule,

Tom
